text:
CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE:
So it's nice to meet you.

By the way, this is not Russian. My t-shirt says
[UKRAINIAN], which

means "reflected reality," which
is why it's written backwards, and it's in Ukrainian.

You have to look in
a mirror to see it the right way around,
but even then. So I'm going to talk
today about schema.org.

I'm Chaals. I work at Yandex. How many people have heard
of-- don't worry about that.

How many people use
schema.org today? A couple. How many people think they
have some idea of what it is?

And how many people are like,
tell me what schema.org is. OK. So we got a big mix.

And how many people know Yandex? How many people
have used Yandex? You've heard of it?

So half of you
haven't heard of it. In California, Yandex is
like, some random startup.

It's actually a billion
company in Russia. It's a search engine
that does maps, and mile,

and money transfer,
and music, and markets, and even things that
don't start with M.

It's a big company in Russia. It does about 60% of all
search in Russia on the web.

So it's one of the
few markets where Google is not at all dominant.

But it's mostly been
a Russian company.
Enough advertising. What is schema.org?
What's the point of schema.org? Schema.org is tagging.

Somebody putting
tags in web pages.   Well, it's not quite like XML.

As I put on the
front title pages, like metadata, like it's 9899.

When search engines
started being a big deal in the mid-'90s,
people were like, oh,

we're going to catalog the web. And so, we're going to have
to put all of this metadata in our pages, so that
search engines find us.

And you may remember if you're
old enough things like meta

keywords, and
descriptions, and stuff, and that was going to
go in search engines, and then suddenly
magically rise to the top.

And you'd use stuff
like Dublin Core. And it was great,
except it didn't happen.

Search engines didn't
use much of the metadata that you put in your pages.

Does anyone know why?   Well, Larry and other
search engine people

said, yeah, we're
not going to do that. But there was a very
sound reason for it. Which is basically,
metadata, because it's not

visible stuff in
the page, would just get stuffed with spam terms for
climbing up the search engine.

So you'd go and look for
any kind of information, and there'd be some page that
had lots of the right keywords,

and the right description,
and you open it up, and it'd be yet
another porn site.

It was basically used for
spamming search engines, and that meant we couldn't
rely on the results.

So search engines
stopped doing it. People who collect
their own information and manage their
own information,

they use that stuff. People who do
metadata, as my mother

says, because that's what
she does, library people, they've been using structured
data in their content

in order to look after
it and manage it. But it never worked
on the open web.

It worked in structured
search engines in libraries all over the world,
and inside companies

that organized
their information. And we've seen a
bunch of stuff--

I've mentioned some names here. I'm going to skip them,
because they'll come up again.

So schema.org is metadata
for search engines.

You put labels in your pages. Keywords in your pages,
and search engines
do actually read it. And why?

What's the difference
between 1999 and now?
Y2K went by. A few other things went by.
Pope from Argentina.   We have peace in our time.

But the search engine
companies have massive amounts of anti-spam detection and
analysis to block spamming,

and to block black hat ACO. So we're much more
confident now in our ability

to look at page which
has keywords all about, whatever it is you
were looking for,

football stadiums for
children, or rowing clubs, and discover whether it really
is a rowing club or a porn

site. So we are able to do
much more with the data

to rely on it more,
because we can quickly detect when people
are telling lies.

Schema.org is an initiative
that came from Google,

but it's Yandex, Yahoo,
Microsoft, like the Bing team,

and Google. The four groups
that are involved in driving it and
making it happen.

I'll come back to that
at the end of the tour. And yes, it's keywords.
It's tagging things. It's not rocket surgery. It's page descriptions.

This web page is
about a business. We sell wigwams,
bridles, and we're

located on 1 Suburban Street,
and our telephone number

is something. Or this is a picture,
a creative work,

and it was created by somebody,
and it was published somewhere.
Information about a book. Information about events.

If for example, you ever had a
web page for a web conference,

you might find that that
page would say, well, what is this page?

It's the page about an event. An event might have a date,
like the 12th of July,

and a location
like PayPal campus, and a name like Open Webcam.

And you put this data
in, and you mark it up. You put explicit data to
say, this is the name,

this is the location,
this is the type of thing.

Conference, or a
flight, or a language. There's a whole
other vocabulary,

which I won't
bother showing you. But I will show
you just quickly.

What do we have. This is all of the
things in schema.org.

Blah, blah, blah. It's just a giant list
of terms and properties.

So I'll tell you what I mean. At term is a thing,
an organization.

An organization has
properties, like its name. It might have a location.

It might have 50
locations, because it's a multinational company
that has offices everywhere and sell burgers.

The location might be a
specific type of location.

So you have a location which
is a burger restaurant. And there's all
these terms in here.

You can look at them
at your leisure. And I'm going to skip them now.
And the basic idea is it's easy. You take some HTML.

What I have here is
a couple of spans. Catcher in the Rye
by JD Salinger.

And Catcher in the
Rye, I made that span, and I've used, in this
example, microdata,

which is a part
of the HTML5 work, to say we have item scope.

So we have all of the things
I'm talking about in here. I will type schema.org/book.

We're talking about a book. And it's got a name,
and it's got an author.

And here's the URL for the
wiki page, the Wikipedia page. This doesn't fit on my
screen, because that's

how presentations go. But you can imagine
the end of the URL.

We started out using
microdata, which is one way of doing markup.

You basically put
attribute inside your HTML. So it's not very complicated.

You just highlight something
and tag it You say, I'm using schema.org/book.

This is the author. This is the thing. RDFa is a different way
of doing the same thing.

How different?   At first glance,
trivially different.

Instead of saying item prop
equals schema.org/something,

you say vocab and type of. Instead of saying
item type is a name,

you say property is a name. You can look at
RDFa or microdata.

Pick which tool suits
you better, and use that. Basically, when you use this
mark up in your pages, we

the search engines
who are indexing it, we go looking for
this stuff on purpose. We want it.

JSON-LD is another way of
doing exactly the same thing.

The difference is
when you have JSON-LD,

it sits in a script
tag on a time. It doesn't appear on
the page anywhere. It's invisible.

But it's the same, this
information and the page before.

They say the same things. You have a name, and a business
with a name and a phone number.

So there are few different
ways, a few different formats you can use, to put your
data into your page.

This really depends
on your tool chain.

How big is the uptake? It's big. In our indexes, each of
those search companies

has their own index. No one will tell you how many
things are in their index.

Google might, because
everyone believes they're the biggest, so
they might say actually how many things
they find, they run,

doesn't want you to know
how much bigger or smaller they are. But all of us in our index
find about 10% of the content

is using schema.org markup. It's only been around
for a couple of years.

So that's three years. So that's a pretty fast uptake. That's a very big distribution
of content on the web,

partly because a lot of the
stuff on the web is old. So a lot of stuff that's new,
and a lot of big services,

are using this markup to make
it possible to find things, and to really know
what they are.

So what does
schema.org describe?

Describes all kinds of things. You can describe a volcano. Turns out, you can say this
is page is about a volcano,

and here's the volcano's fax
number and opening hours.

It's very useful to know when
a volcano's opening hours are. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]?

CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE:
Well, it turns out that no one's actually,
as far as we know, marked up the opening
hours of a volcano.
Medical conditions. Movie review rental stores.

How many people have
been in their life to a movie rental store? This is a kind of
local business, right?
It's a physical location. Defense establishment.

Sort of thing you
find all over the web. It's like, oh, where's my
local defense establishment?

I might wander down
and pay them a visit. HVAC Business.

I saw that and went,
what is an HVAC business? So I looked in
the documentation,
and said, HVAC business. An HVAC business.

OK. So there's someone told
me what that really is.

It's heating, ventilation,
and air conditioning. Who knew?

But there's a lot
of detail in there. Everything. You've just got all
kinds of things.

I should have put an asterisk
here too, but I didn't.

Some of the fundamental
ideas behind schema.org were, keep it simple. Why do we use this really
simple RDFa or microdata markup?

If it's simple,
people get it right. If we make something
really complicated,

super powerful, super
precise, ontology describing every single thing,
people get it wrong.

If we ask webmasters to
decide whether they're talking about an
event invitation,

or a possibility of
going to an event,

or a notice of an event
that you can turn up to,

they will randomly
choose one of the three, and we will have to
handle all three.

And that just means you do
a whole lot of aliasing, and you get no value. If the terms aren't different
from each other in ways

that simple developers
understand, and in my case,

in Russia, where most
developers' level of English is pretty basic, if they don't
understand the difference,

they're not going
to get it right. So it's really important to
actually keep it very simple.

It's a very flat structure. Everything is a
rough approximation. Everything in schema.org, every
term, every type, has a name,

and its URL is
http://schema.org/Whatever. That's it.

There's no complicated
nesting paths, and substructure in the
way things are named.

There are locations,
and then there are subtypes of locations. So you can have a location--
this is a location.

You can have, this location
is a movie rental store, which is a type of location.

It's also a type of business. And there are very
basic data types.
Text. You have URLs, date, times.

And you can have float
or integer numbers. Everybody knows the
difference, right?

Can someone-- how many
people can tell me

why prices should be
written in integers? AUDIENCE: Because
it is floating,

it's some approximation
of the value when you add two numbers
together, [INAUDIBLE].

CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE:
How many people understood the explanation? Right. Half.

This is kind of complicated. If we say decimal number, then
maybe people would get it. But even this is sort of dicey.

But yeah, you do need
it for certain things.

Recently, we started making
schema do a few more things.

Action, because we
all want action. What are actions?

The web does things. You don't just look
at pages about books.

You don't just look
at pages about movies. You watch the movie. You buy the book.
You steal the video game. No, don't steal the video game. That's very naughty.

I'll come back to video
games in a minute. But, for example, take a page
like aeroflot.ru, as you might,

if your Russian's good. You can book a flight,
reserve a seat.

You can check in
for your flight. You can find out
where on Earth they left your luggage
after you've arrived.

These are all things
that the website does. And if you go into a modern
browser, or modern search

engine, email clients,
Gmail, Yandex mail,

they start to show
these things directly. Your search engine
result is no longer

Aeroflot, and the
first line and a half of description about Aeroflot. Or United Airlines, remember
to fill in content here.
It's actually got Iberia.

Book a flight. Check in. Those links are in the result
in the search engine page.

Or you get an email
with your flight ticket, and your email program actually
has a button on it saying,

this is a flight reservation. Click here to check in. So you don't have to go hunting
through, and find the URL,

and do that stuff. If you mark up where
the check in thing is,

then software, because
it's clever, but not very, can actually find that, and
put that front and center

in the user interface
to make it faster for you, to get where
you're trying to go.

So the idea of actions
is to mark that stuff up.

There are a few simple things. I have examples here, which
are kind of randomly selected.

Basically, you have a potential
action on a website somewhere. In this example, the
type-- I've used JSON-LD,

because I copied
and pasted examples from the documentation. It's a SearchAction, so you're
searching for some thing.

And the target is a patent. It's
example.com/search=something.

And then, we've got some
parameters about it. So you have to have a name.

The maximum length of the
name is going to be 100. This tells you when we put up
the link in the email client,

or in the search engine results. We know what the
parameters have to be, so we can put the
right size text box,

or we can tell to
you which fields are required before we bother
sending you to the web page,

and finding out
that, no, you've got to go back and fill
half of it in again.

And another example, a little
bit more complication, it's

like a two page example,
because it's really complex. That makes it 10
lines, 12 lines.

You've got a potentialAction,
which is a BuyAction. Go on, spend money, do stuff.

You have an entry
point into the process. You can buy something.

And we know things,
like how the data should be encoded to send it
there, what type of data

you're going to get. These are just simple things
that, if you have your website,

and you want people to be
able to get directly in it, you have to explain
what you're asking for.

Because what happens is that
people don't necessarily start at your website.

They're linking straight
in from their email. And in the Yandex browser, I
got Aeroflut in the address bar.

I actually get a button
right up in the address bar in the URL bar at the top. I get the book flight,
check in, and I

think there's one other
one that it'll put there. So people go straight in.

They never even see
the search page. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE].   CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE:
That's done by the browser.

Pulling the data
out of the page. Or in that case,
because that browser

is linked to our message engine,
when you get suggestions, some

of those are your
history, some of those are your search
history, if you have a search history on Yandex.

So the browser is
doing processing. It might be going backwards
and forwards to the-- it

might not you. You might say,
no, don't do that, and it only does
stuff in your history.

But it can analyze the
stuff and do it on the fly. And you'll get back a result.
You've completed the action. Yay. You've made the order. You've got an order number.

You've got a
confirmation number, and we're processing it. Get back to us, eventually,
if you're lucky.

No, it doesn't work like that. Every eCommerce
system is perfect.

All products are delivered
on time in good condition, if not earlier.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE].

CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE: Shh. Don't tell her.   As I said, the goal is, keep
it as simple as possible.

Always. So simple that it's
hard for people to get it wrong if
they think a bit,

if they read the documentation. But as simple as
possible is part

of how you should do
things, but no simpler.
Don't make things too simple.

So we've recently been
working on putting in stuff about sports,
sporting events, sporting
teams, rock bands, TV series.

And they turn out to be
quite complicated collections of information.
How many people here go to IMDb?
So I'm just about unique. I think I've been there twice. I don't go to the movie's other.

And how many people
watch some TV series?
Legitimately? Good job.

So the example I picked
here is San Francisco 49ers. And the quarterback
is Joe Montana.

If you're old enough.   Sometimes. It turns out sometimes,
they have a quarterback

who's not Joe Montana. Actually, for most
of their history. So you can say, the 49ers have
an athlete that is Joe Montana.

Looks like, well,
actually, no, they don't even have an athlete
who's Joe Montana anymore. He's not part of the team.

So how do we deal with that? And we came up with a
beautifully complicated

structure, with roles which
are work in progress do.

Add a layer of indirection,
because every problem can be solved by a
layer of indirection.

So instead of saying, the
49ers have an athlete who's Joe Montana, you'll say,
49ers have an athlete.

And there's his role.   We have a few roles, like
performance roles, or actors.

And the role is an
abstract concept.

Actually, whatever
this role is, there's an athlete who does it
who's called Joe Montana,

and there's a start
date, which is 1979, and there's an end
date, which is 1992,

but I haven't put
it in the example. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE].

CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE:
This athlete is actually the same
as this athlete. That's kind of
dodgy, but it works.
It doesn't have to be the same.

It just turns out that we've
only got one athlete property. AUDIENCE: His role is
a subset of athlete.

And second statement, athlete,
is maybe a subset of role?

CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE:
So we may have chosen the names badly. We probably have. But the basic idea is role
is this abstract concept.

I stole a picture
from the internet that explains the idea.
And it's slightly different. This example is Ghostbusters. Ghostbusters has an actor.

You could just say Ghostbusters
has the actor Bill Murray. Done. And then you could say,
Bill Murray's character name

is Doctor Peter Venkman. That's great, except
that Bill Murray actually

has a lot of character names
in a lot of different places. And if you just say, Bill
Murray's character name

is Doctor Peter Venkman, and
Ghostbusters has Bill Murray, it's like, great.

Those are two statements,
but they're support. And you say, Bill
Murray's character name

is also Joe Bloggs, you've
got three statements, and you got no way of figuring
out how to separate them out.

And that's why we put this
performance role in the middle. So for Ghostbusters,
there's an actor,

which has these
various properties. And for some other movie,
not being a movie buff,

I can't really tell
you anything else Bill Murray's ever been
in, which is probably almost unique in this room.

AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]. CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE: So
anyway, in these other movies, you have an actor who happens
to be the same Bill Murray,

but he has different
attributes within the context of that role.

So that sort of takes
a tiny bit of thinking. This is really an
abstract concept, right?

Everything else so far in
schema has been pretty concrete. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE].

CHAALS MCCATHIENEVILLE: No, no. He must become a
primary on his page. This page is Bill Murray.

Yeah, yeah. It's a very good point,
and you're right. On Bill Murray's page, this
page is about Bill Murray.

And Bill Murray has a
performance role actor in Ghostbusters.

Actually, he has a role where
the movie is Ghostbusters, and the character
name is Peter Venkman.

And he has another role where
the movie is Caddy Shack, and presumably, he has a
character that all of you know.

Because you're all cleverer
than me, apparently.

So we can describe
almost everything.

I'm going to come
back to Bill Murray. But I'm going to talk a little
bit about what we're doing now. It seems if you look at
the vocabulary we have,

we don't love hockey stadiums. We don't have a term
for hockey stadium. It's like, this does not
go down well in Russia.
In Russia, hockey plays you.

We don't have anything for game. Not that there are many games
on the web, but apparently,

there's still a few people
who like to play them. We don't have anything
for translation.

You can markup
your book, but you can't say there's a
translation of another book. Or we have men's clothing store,
and we have clothing store.

There's nothing for
children's clothing, or for lingerie,
or for milliners, or for various other
kinds of shops, yet.

The basic point is, because
this stuff is pragmatic and done

on an as needs basis, it's
also a kind of scrappy.

So I want to talk a
little bit about how the whole thing happens. And it started out
because R.V. Guha,

the guy who, among
other things, made the What's Related button
in Netscape-- you all

remember Netscape? It had this button,
What's Related, and you could go and find
things that were similar.

So really, this is
partying like it's 1999. This is not new ideas.

This is stuff that people
have implemented, shipped, reimplemented,
re-imagined, and reshipped.

We've sort of opened it up. So right now, there's a
public discussion forum,

which is discussing
vocabularies. What kind of things do we need? We need video games.

We need hockey stadiums. You can describe a lake,
or a sea, or a river,

but you can't
describe an island. So, there's random gaps.

People write out
their proposals, and put them on the web
somewhere, write to the list and say, look,
here's my proposal,

and the search engines decide. The four search engines
actually look at it

and say, well,
yeah, we'll do this. No, we don't think
this is ready.

Translation should
be coming soon. But it was part of
a giant proposal

from a bunch of
professional librarians. And we looked at
their giant proposal and we said, yeah,
that's really good.
It's based on Fervor. Anyone know what Fervor is?

Fervor is a standard for
describing the relationship between various instances of
a work, and the work itself.

So you have Romeo and Juliet. Everyone knows what
Romeo and Juliet is.

And then you have performances
of Romeo and Juliet, and you have scripts
of Romeo and Juliet, and you have performances
based on particular scripts.

And you have Baz Luhrmann's
film of Romeo and Juliet, which is different from Roman
Polanski's Romeo and Juliet.

And describing how
all of these things are related to each other,
hardcore librarians have really

detailed ways of managing
all of the relationships, and being able to figure out
what was descended from what.

West Side Story is based
on Romeo and Juliet, but is not quite
Romeo and Juliet.
It's just the same story. So they have this huge things.

They said, yeah,
schema.org needs that, so you can describe the
relationship between all of these creative
works on the web.

And we're like, yeah,
professional librarians

get that right 80% of the time. We reckon webmasters
will be lucky to get

that right 8% of the time. So we're going to take some
things out, like 99% of it.

And we got down to a
few relationships that are really key, and we think are
clear enough and easily enough

distinguished that
they will go in. But they're not there yet.

There's another part of the
evolution, how it happened. We started out, microdata.

If you look at schema.org
today, and you look at the FAQ, it's says, why do
you use microdata?

And in the FAW, it
says, well, microdata is a very pragmatic choice. It's very easy for
webmasters to use.

It's part of the HTML5 standard,
and lots of web developers know it.

If you look at the GitHub
page for schema.org, there's a poll
request, saying yeah,

but we don't say that anymore,
because we no longer believe it. We discovered, for
example, microdata,

it's very hard to change the
order of the relationship. So doing that thing about Bill
Murray as an actor in a movie,

and a movie has
actor Bill Murray, you need one property
to point each way.

That means you've got to have
twice as many property names. That means the whole
thing gets bloated,

and it's hard to process. RDFa and JSON-LD
both just allow you

to invert the direction
of the relationship. So it's quite easy.

You can do it with microdata,
but it does your hitting.

You can't mix
vocabularies in microdata. You say, schema.org,
everything's

got to be schema.org term. You can't use a Wikipedia
term, or some formal vocabulary

term for medical
conditions on top of that. There's no way of actually
marking that correctly

in microdata. People have JSON-LD
and RDFa tool chains,

because you can do that
using JSON-LD and RDFa.

Because what it
doesn't say here is, don't say the formal
data model of schema.org,

the actual way we think
about it underneath, is RDF.

So if you know RDF, we're
really, really doing RDF. It's what we're really, really
putting on 10% of the web.

And all those famous
semantic web link data, astronautic stuff
that will never work, turns out to work really well
if you do the simple things.

But it makes the
complex things possible, which is what we need, and
what microdata is very bad for.

As I've said, we
started at Google.

We're kind of opening up. Over the last two
or three years, this thing has become
much more public, much

more publicly driven. They added Yahoo as sort
of a launch partner,

and then Microsoft
got on board, and then Yandex got on board
within a couple of months.

We've recently shifted the
actual content of the website from internal Google
stuff that was

horrible to try and deal with. We had to beg someone at Google
to change things to GitHub,

so people like me can just go
make a change, a poll request, and change the documentation.

We're trying to put out more
information about what we do. We're trying to put
up more examples.

We would like to do
more translations. We, Yandex, would
particularly like to translate this
stuff into Russian,

because most of our target
market speaks Russian. So what else is coming?

We need to clean
up the vocabulary. If you can describe
a river as different

from a sea or a
canal, you should be able to describe an
island as being an island. Because there are
few around the world.
You go on holidays to them. That's what they're for. Australia, yeah.

We need to do more work
on roles and actions. Neither of them are
really finished yet.

They're quite complicated. We've spent a long
time getting them to a point where we
think they're workable.

And we've only just
started putting roles into the vocabulary.

But for stuff like
TV series, we're going to need a lot more
than what we've got already. Or for sporting statistics,
the history of cricket matches.

Other important things. And relating to
other vocabularies.

So, do people know
Facebook's open graph? It's similar.

There's metadata you
put in your pages, and it basically provides
the kind of information that Facebook systems
are interested in.

This is about a person,
and I have a cat. And here's a picture of me
and my cat, who is my friend.

I had to get my cat
a Facebook account, so I could have a friend. OpenGraph is very, very simple.

There are probably more
pages using OpenGraph
